bestBHT.bht: With intense desire, Jesus earnestly longed to eat this Passover meal with His disciples before He suffered. It was to be His last meal before His sacrifice, making it a significant moment as the typological ordinances disappeared. The phrase with desire I have desired expresses His intense longing, using a Hebrew form of expression to denote strong desire. He desired to share this Passover with His disciples, not just for the sake of the meal, but to manifest Himself further to them in this solemn parting.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: With desire... earnestly have I longed."
It was to be His last 'before He suffered'—and so became 'Christ our Passover sacrificed for us'.
Albert Barnes: This is a Hebrew form of expression, and means 'I have greatly desired.'"
The reasons why he desired this we may suppose to have been: Before I suffer - Before I die.
Marvin Vincent: With desire I have desired. Expressing intense desire. Compare John 3:29, rejoiceth with joy; Acts 4:17, threaten with threatening.
Philip Schaff: With desire I have desired. A Hebrew form of expression, denoting strong desire.
One ground of the strong desire was the certainty that it would be the last one, hence peculiarly solemn and important.
The feast at its very beginning takes on a farewell character.
Archibald T. Robertson: With desire I have desired (επιθυμια επεθυμησα). A Hebraism common in the LXX."
Associative instrumental case of substantive and first aorist active indicative of same like a cognate accusative.
Peculiar to Luke is all this verse.
John Gill: With desire have I desired to eat this passover with you before I suffer...

...not merely does he say this on account of the passover, as it was God's ordinance; though as he was made under the law, and that was in his heart, he had a great regard to it, and a delight in it...

...two reasons are suggested in the text why he so greatly desired to eat this passover; the one is, because he should eat it 'with' his disciples; an emphasis lies on the phrase, 'with you', to whom, and not so much to the passover, and the eating of that, was his desire.
John Wesley: With desire have I desired — That is, I have earnestly desired it.
He desired it, both for the sake of his disciples, to whom he desired to manifest himself farther, at this solemn parting.
For the sake of his whole Church, that he might institute the grand memorial of his death.

bhtAttempts.bht: With intense desire, Jesus eagerly longed to eat this Passover meal with his disciples before he would suffer. This meal, His last one before His sacrifice, marked a significant turning point as the typological ordinances faded away and Christ, our Passover, was sacrificed for us. The phrase with desire I have desired expresses His deep longing, using a Hebrew form of expression denoting a strong desire. In desiring to share this Passover with His disciples, Jesus sought to manifest Himself further to them in this solemn farewell gathering. Moreover, His desire to partake in this meal bore the significance of instituting the grand memorial of His death for the sake of His whole Church.

With intense desire, Jesus earnestly longed to eat this Passover meal with His disciples before He suffered. It was to be His last meal before His sacrifice, making it a significant moment as the typological ordinances disappeared. The phrase with desire I have desired expresses His intense longing, using a Hebrew form of expression to denote strong desire. He desired to share this Passover with His disciples, not just for the sake of the meal, but to manifest Himself further to them in this solemn parting.

With intense desire, Jesus earnestly longed to eat this Passover meal with His disciples before He suffered. It was to be His last meal before His sacrifice, marking the disappearance of the typological ordinances. The phrase with desire I have desired conveys His deep longing, using a Hebrew form of expression denoting strong desire. He desired to share this Passover with His disciples, not only for the sake of the meal, but also to manifest Himself further to them in this solemn farewell gathering.

With intense desire, Jesus earnestly longed to eat this Passover meal with His disciples before He suffered. It was His last meal before His sacrifice, signifying the fading away of typological ordinances. The phrase with desire I have desired expresses His deep longing, using a Hebrew form of expression for strong desire. He desired to share this Passover with His disciples, manifesting Himself further in this solemn farewell gathering. This meal held significance not only for His disciples, but also for the entire Church as He instituted the memorial of His death.

With intense desire, Jesus eagerly longed to eat this Passover meal with his disciples before he would suffer. This meal, His last one before His sacrifice, marked a significant turning point as the typological ordinances faded away and Christ, our Passover, was sacrificed for us. In desiring to share this Passover with His disciples, Jesus sought to manifest Himself further to them in this solemn farewell gathering. Moreover, His desire to partake in this meal bore the significance of instituting the grand memorial of His death for the sake of His whole Church.
